title: Linear momentum of a ascending leaking bucket

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students set up the Atwood machine shown in the figure above, which consists of a light string passing over a pulley whose mass and friction are negligible. A counterweight of constant mass is connected to the right end of the string. A bucket full of water is connected to the left end of the string. The counterweight has a mass less than that of the full bucket, but greater than that of the empty bucket. At time <math alttext="t equals 0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> the system is released from rest with the bucket full. At the same time, water begins to flow out of the bucket through a hole on the side near the bottom. The graph above shows the height of the counterweight above its initial position as a function of time between time <math alttext="t equals 0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the instant the counterweight returns to its initial position. The bucket and counterweight continue moving long after this time. (a) At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> the mass of the bucket and the water is equal to the mass of the counterweight. Which time interval identified below contains the time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer. Interval 1: <math alttext="0 seconds is less than t, which is less than or equal to 0.5 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Interval 2: <math alttext="0.5 second is less than t, which is less than or equal to 1.5 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Interval 3: <math alttext="1.5 seconds is less than t, which is less than or equal to 2.5 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Interval 4: <math alttext="2.5 seconds is less than t, which is less than or equal to 3.0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

A counterweight of constant mass is connected to the right end of the string. A bucket full of water is connected to the left end of the string. The counterweight has a mass less than that of the full bucket, but greater than that of the empty bucket. At the same time, water begins to flow out of the bucket through a hole on the side near the bottom. The graph above shows the height of the counterweight above its initial position as a function of time between time <math alttext="t equals 0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the instant the counterweight returns to its initial position. (a) At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> the mass of the bucket and the water is equal to the mass of the counterweight. Which time interval identified below contains the time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer. Interval 1: <math alttext="0 seconds is less than t, which is less than or equal to 0.5 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Interval 2: <math alttext="0.5 second is less than t, which is less than or equal to 1.5 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Interval 3: <math alttext="1.5 seconds is less than t, which is less than or equal to 2.5 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Interval 4: <math alttext="2.5 seconds is less than t, which is less than or equal to 3.0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
(b) At what time is the potential energy of the counterweight-Earth system at a maximum? Justify your answer.

The students approximate the acceleration of the counterweight using the function <math alttext="a of t, equals 1.8 minus 1.8, t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1.8</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>1.8</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the interval <math alttext="0 seconds is less than t, which is less than 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Note that positive acceleration represents upward acceleration for the counterweight.(c) Describe how this acceleration function matches the given position vs. time graph above of the counterweight during this interval.
(d) Explain why this function does NOT correctly model the acceleration of the counterweight over a long period of time, assuming that the system is able to move for a very long time.

The students are told that the mass of the counterweight is <math alttext="10 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the mass of the bucket with water in it is approximately given by the equation <math alttext="M of t, equals 14.4 times e raised to the negative 0.369, t power, kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>14.4</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.369</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="t is less than or equal to 8 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume any action-reaction forces between the bucket and the water draining are negligible.(e) Explain how the students could use this information along with the acceleration function <math alttext="a of t, equals 1.8 minus 1.8, t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1.8</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>1.8</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to calculate the total linear momentum of the system consisting of the bucket, the water in the bucket, the pulley, and the counterweight at time <math alttext="t equals 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
